Discrimination
Last spring and again this winter the News-Letter
has contained accounts of discrimination against members of the Hopkins community by local merchants. In
response to these articles many students have expressed
their objections to this prejudiced policy and asked Nyhat
they might do to correct the situation.
However our elders remind us that we must be
"practical"—after all, some potential donor to the University, might be a little prejudiced and get upset at the
thought of Negroes attending Johns, Hopkins.

money for this University under these circumstances.

patronized by Hopkins students - make a practice of
singling out certain individuals as undesirable because of
their racial background.

at Hopkins by citing the fact that "their problem is one

In a survey conducted in the
past month by the News-Letter,
it was found that most of the
eating places in the neighborhood of the Homewood Campus
will not serve Negro Hopkins
students, and that some refuse
service to Oriental students as
well.
Among the 28 eating establishments investigated (all of them
in the immediate vicinity
of
Homewood or frequented by
Hopkins students), 36% stated to
the News-Letter that they
would
serve Negro students; 77%
said
they would serve Oriental
students.
In each of these places,
the
owner or manager was
questioned about his establishment's
general policy toward colored
patrons, how it applied to Hopkins
students in particular and the
reasons for this policy.
Color Bar at Counter
When these results are categorized according to type of
business, the results are as follows:
Among the 10 stores featuring
fountain service (such as drug
stores and ice cream parlors),
six will serve Negro students,
eight will serve Oriental students. Two of the three sandwich shops interviewed will
serve Negroes, all will serve
Orientals. Out of four lunch and
coffee shops, one will serve
Negroes and three will serve
Orientals. But among the nine
restaurants and "good" eating
places interviewed only one will
serve Negroes, and seven will
serve Orientals.
These last two categories are
of most concern to the Hopkins
Negroes. Many of them have refused to attend Hopkins dances
and other social functions because there is no suitable place
where they can take dates afterward; neither, they point out,
is there any eating place where
they can sit and talk with
friends late at night.

asked by the News-Letter for a

assist in helping to stop the discrimination. . ." Dr. Shaffer and
Dean of Students W. Kelso Morrill both agreed to write letters
to the local merchants about this
matter.

To the Editors:
I wish to call your attention
to the proposal by Student Council Rrepresentative Bill Brandon
concerning the holding of a mock
political convention at Hopkins.
A school such as Hopkins that
is dedicated to science has a
student body that is uninterested in the main functioning of
American Government. A convention of this type would tend
to initiate political thought
and interest on the campus.

With the evolvement of many
of the Hopkins faculty in matters of national and local politics,
this presents a unique chance
for Hopkins students to learn
about politics in an informal
way from people. who are mak
ing the news.

Needless to say, this idea has
gone over well at several colleges
where it has been tried. The most
famous of these is Oberlin, where
it has become a tradition. I feel
that there is no better way of
educating the future voting public in the workings and the significance of a political convention.
